Award.AwardTitle: Inductive Mechanisms in Arthropod Germ Line Specification
Award.AbstractNarration: Eggs and sperm are made by special cells called germ cells. Germ cells are critical not only to organismal survival but also to species survival and evolution, because they are the only cell type capable of producing the next generation. It is therefore critical to understand the genetic and molecular mechanisms that make sure germ cells are specified in embryos. Studies using traditional model organisms such as mice and fruit flies have suggested that some animals use an 'inheritance' mechanism to specify germ cells, whereby germ cell-determining substances are placed into developing eggs before embryonic development begins. In other animals, an 'inductive' mechanism operates, whereby cells exchange signals to determine which cells should become germ cells. For decades it was thought that most animals used the inheritance mechanism, and that mammals were exceptional in using the inductive mechanism. Prior research by the PI challenged this assumption by discovering the first example of a non-mammalian animal that uses the inheritance mechanism. To make this discovery, they studied germ cells in a cricket called Gryllus bimaculatus. The current project will extend this novel finding by determining whether the signals used to specify germ cells are actually the same in both mammals and crickets. If this proves to be the case, it could mean that the same signaling mechanism was used to specify germ cells in a last common ancestor of all animals. This work has high transformative potential, as it will have a radical impact on our understanding of how germ cells are specified in diverse animals, and how the mechanisms used to specify germ cells evolved. The current project will also develop new educational tools that use science fiction films to engage both the general public and university undergraduates in the study of developmental biology and genetics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this work was to discover molecular and genetic mechanisms that regulate the formation of germ cells in a cricket model organism. Germ cells make eggs and sperm, and thus are critical for organismal fertility and survival and for species evolution. We had previously shown that the mechanism of specifying germ cells in the cricket Gryllus bimaculatus was likely very different from the mechanisms that had been discovered for most of the well-studied animal models previously used for laboratory studies of germ cell formation.

 

With this award, we first wished to test the hypothesis that a specific signaling mechanism, called the BMP signaling pathway, was required to specify germ cells in this cricket. We performed multiple experiments that provided support for this hypothesis. This is an exciting finding because it is the first time that the identity of any signaling pathway for making germ ells has been discovered in an invertebrate, and it is the same signaling pathway used by mice and salamanders, which were previously thought to be the only animals using this pathway for germ cell specification.

 

Our second goal under this award was to discover the mechanisms that allowed or instructed specific cells of the mesoderm (the layer of animal cells that normally generates muscle) to become germ cells. To achieve this goal we established and documented many new tools and techniques to make it easier to work with and manipulate the genes of this cricket, including a thorough description of embryonic development and a guide to recognizing the different developmental stages, a video protocol showing how to inject different molecules and chemicals into cricket eggs, customizable devices to hold dozens of cricket eggs in place for microscopy or injection, and CRISPR/Cas9 technology to manipulate the cricket genome.

 

While developing additional techniques to follow the fates of individual cells during the development of cricket embryos, we performed an analysis of how the earliest cells of the cricket egg become organized to make the very beginnings of the cricket embryo. This led to our developing a mathematical model that accurately predicts the behavior of these early egg cells, and suggests specific hypotheses for the cellular mechanisms that could be controlling this behavior. We hope to test these hypotheses in future work.

 

As an extension of that work on how cells behave in early insect eggs, we began to investigate the size and shape of insect eggs generally, because our mathematical model predicted that egg size and shape could affect the way that cells move inside the egg. This led to a new project where we first developed novel computational methods to search centuries’ worth of literature and recover over 10,000 measurements of nearly 7,000 species of insect. We then used this enormous dataset to ask what factors might contribute to the evolution of insect egg size and shape. We found evidence that the places where eggs are laid might influence the evolution of egg morphology in insects. This work captured the imaginations of many people outside of science, and thus received significant national and international media attention:

 

Law, Y.-H., 2019. Why some insect eggs are spherical while others look like hot dogs. Sci. News July 3.

https://www.sciencenews.org/article/evolution-insect-egg-size-shape-diversity-database

 

Callier, V., 2019. Ecology, Not Physics, Explains Diversity of Insect Eggs. The Scientist July 3.

https://www.the-scientist.com/news-opinion/ecology--not-physics--explains-diversity-of-insect-eggs-66067

 

Guglielmi, G., 2019. The Symphony of Cells: The biologist using insect eggs to overturn evolutionary doctrine. Nature 571, 24-26.

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-019-02040-6

 

Simon, C., 2019. Debunking old hypotheses, The Harvard Gazette.

https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2019/07/harvards-extavour-debunks-old-hypotheses-on-insect-eggs/

 

Marfany, G., 2019. Opinión: Sinfonía celular, El Nacional.CAT, Barcelona, Spain.

https://www.elnacional.cat/es/opinion/gemma-marfany-sinfonia-celular_401302_102.html

 

 

Our third goal was to see if a group of genes called Hox genes played any role in making sure that germ cells developed in the correct place within the cricket embryo. We chose to look at these genes because they are conserved across all animals, and are important for giving different body regions their specific identities. We indeed found that these genes are required to ensure that germ cells develop only in a specific region of the embryo, and that the right number of germ cells is specified.

 

Finally, many young scientists were trained under this award, including six undergraduate students, nine graduate students, and five postdoctoral researchers. Three of the undergraduates are currently PhD candidates, one is in medical school, and two report planning to pursue STEM careers. Three of the graduate students are currently postdoctoral researchers, five of them are continuing to pursue their PhD research, and one of them entered a genome analysis career within a public research institute. Three of the postdoctoral researchers are currently Assistant Professors at a College or University, and two have pursued other STEM careers.

 

We published 19 papers peer reviewed over the course of the funding period, and we are preparing three additional papers for submission to peer reviewed journals.
